name: Palermo
fun_fact: Fun fact: Palermo is considered the street food capital of Italy, with a culinary tradition dating back to Arab rule in the 9th century. The city's markets have been serving fried street food for over a millennium!

hero_dishes.name: Arancine
hero_dishes.description: Golden, crispy rice balls filled with risotto, ragu, and sometimes mozzarella. Shaped like oranges, reflecting Sicily's citrus heritage.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Named after their orange-like shape, arancine have been eaten for a millennium. Arabs introduced rice to Sicily, while Normans introduced breading as a preservation method for travelers.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Che Palle on Via Maqueda 270 for creative varieties like porcini mushroom; Forno Storico Pietro Marino in Ballar√≤ market for traditional versions; look for places that fry to order for extra crispy results

hero_dishes.name: Panelle
hero_dishes.description: Chickpea flour fritters, crispy on the outside and creamy inside, served in sesame-seeded buns often paired with crocch√® (potato croquettes).
hero_dishes.origin_story: Arabs first brought chickpea milling to Sicily, creating 'chickpea polenta' as food for the poor. Today it's beloved street food enjoyed by all.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mercato di Capo for traditional market stands; Nni Franco U Vastiddaru at Via Vittorio Emanuele 102; the husband-wife-son team at Piazza Ballar√≤ who drop panelle fresh into bubbling oil

hero_dishes.name: Sfincione
hero_dishes.description: Thick, fluffy Sicilian pizza with a focaccia-like crust, topped with tomato sauce, onions, anchovies, oregano, and caciocavallo cheese. The name derives from Latin/Greek for 'sponge'.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This traditional Sicilian pizza evolved as a hearty, filling street food with its thick dough left to rise for hours, creating an airy, sponge-like texture.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Panificio Graziano near Statua della Libert√† (local favorite); Panificio Pietro Bonaccorso in Vucciria market (made fresh 3x daily); Antica Focacceria San Francesco for a classic version

signature_drinks.name: Marsala Wine
signature_drinks.description: Italy's oldest DOC fortified wine made from Grillo, Inzolia, Catarratto grapes. Ranges from dry to sweet with ~18% alcohol.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Originally served as an aperitif in the 1700s-1800s, now often used in cooking. Visit CiCala for incredible traditional Marsala selection, or Taverna Azzurra in Vucciria for ‚Ç¨1 marsala

signature_drinks.name: Sicilian Blood Orange Juice
signature_drinks.description: Fresh-squeezed juice from Sicily's famous blood oranges and lemons, sold at market stands.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Grab a fresh juice at Succhi Freschi Ballar√≤ market stand for an authentic refreshing break while exploring the markets
